When Sir Alex arrived from Aberdeen in the autumn
of 1986, Manchester United were in decline.

39.text:
They hadn't won the league since 1967 and
found themselves second-from-bottom in the

43.text:
old First Division. Ferguson set about overhauling
every aspect of life at the club, bringing

49.text:
discipline back into the changing by eradicating
the destructive drinking culture.

53.text:
“The players didn’t really know a lot
about him. One player who did was Gordon Strachan

58.text:
who played with him at Aberdeen. A lot of
United players asked Strachan what he was

63.text:
like. Strachan laughed and said, “There’s
going to be a big change of scene here’.

68.text:
He gathered the players in the small gymnasium
at the Cliff and said, ‘I’m not happy

73.text:
about this culture of drinking. I’m hearing
things around Manchester from people saying

78.text:
you’ve been spotted out. I don't like what
I’m hearing. It’s not professional’.

82.text:
There was some resistance to that change.
‘This is what it’s always been like…

87.text:
this is what it’s like at every club’…
Maybe that was how it had been. But that wasn’t

90.text: how Sir Alex Ferguson wanted it be.

93.text:
“He scared me to death, pretty much. I played
under fear. I was always fearful of his hairdryer

99.text:
tellings-off. I didn’t want to let him down.
Probably Liverpool was the worst one. He told

103.text:
me at half-time he was kicking me out of my
house and putting me back in digs. My girlfriend

109.text:
had moved up from Birmingham – she had to
go back home and we had to split up. My dog

115.text:
had to get sold. My car had to get sold. And
I had to go out there and prove to him that I could play.”

122.text:
To execute his root and branch reform, Sir
Alex transformed the scouting network and

127.text:
youth set-up. United’s success for the next
27 years would be built on homegrown products.

135.text:
“He put Brian Kidd in charge of the youth
in the local area and he got a load more scouts

143.text: and they got a load more active.”

145.text:
“He kept coming up and telling the likes
of me, Paul Ince, Denis Irwin… all players

155.text:
in that kind of time, he’d say, ‘These
players – i.e. Nicky Butt, Paul Scholes,

162.text:
Gary Neville, David Beckham – are going
to be taking your places soon. He believed

167.text:
in what was coming through and 
it proved that he was right.”

173.text:
“Sometimes when we were playing reserve
games, he’d be watching and after the game,

179.text:
win or lose, he’d come in and say his piece.
But he’d always knock on that, ‘You’re

185.text:
looking to play for the first team, you’re
one stop away from playing for the first team’.

189.text:
Say it was a bad game, you’d all have to
improve.”

192.text:
“He was there at the nights with the youth
team players after being with the first team.

197.text:
You’d turn round and he’d be sat on the
bench next to you. Of course the players look

201.text:
over to the bench… ‘Oh, the manager’s
here!’ And obviously they play harder, they

204.text:
play faster, they want to impress him. He
was everywhere. Just that force of energy

209.text:
and ambition and drive that lifted the whole
club. Everybody else was then infected by

215.text:
that same sort of drive. The Manchester United
of history and the Busby Babes was about youth

223.text:
and that core of homegrown players gave them
the spirit of Man United back.”

231.text:
Initially, Sir Alex’s shake-up didn't have
the desired affect. It is widely reported

236.text:
he was close to being sacked after a rocky
start to his fourth season. But the Manchester

242.text:
United board stuck with him. In 1993, United
won their first league title in 26 years adding

250.text:
to their FA Cup, League Cup and 
Cup Winners’ Cup triumphs under Ferguson.

257.text:
At the heart of his success was Ferguson’s
skilful man management. His reputation as

262.text:
a fearsome dictator kept the players on their
toes while his softer side earned their loyalty.

267.text:
“He knew how to give you a rollocking. He
knew how to put his arms around you and comfort

274.text:
you… wasn’t that often. He just had a unique
way of getting his point across.”

283.text:
“Steve Bruce’s wife, Janet, was in hospital
– she was having a back operation. We’re

290.text:
playing, so Brucey left his mobile phone on
during the game. We came in at half-time,

298.text:
things weren’t going well – this was at
Old Trafford. Se we’re sitting in the dressing

301.text:
room and Steve’s phone goes off.
We’re all sitting there, looking at each

306.text:
other wondering who’s it is. I knew it wasn't
me, I knew it wasn’t Denis – Denis did

311.text:
have a phone but it was never switched on
anyway. Big Pete, straightaway as normal going,

317.text:
‘It wasn’t me’ and maybe his eyes giving
away who it was. Then we looked at Bruce and

323.text:
you could just see his face and persona: It
was me. The gaffer’s ran across, grabbed

330.text:
the phone, had a go at Steve Bruce, Steve
Bruce had a go and tried to tell him his wife’s

335.text:
in hospital. ‘I don’t care if your wife’s
in hospital!’ and just threw the phone,

340.text:
against the wall, towards the bin 
and smashed the phone.”

343.text: “When Sir Alex used to get on my back it used to make me play better. We were playing Leeds

347.text:
away and I got an absolute bollocking at half-time.
If I’m being honest, at the time I was thinking,

358.text:
‘I wasn’t that bad’. So, I went out
and we ended up winning the game. When I came

365.text:
back in, one of the younger lads came up to
me and said, ‘You know when the gaffer give

373.text:
you a right go, he come round and said, ‘Ah,
he’ll be alright now’’.”

379.text:
In 2008, United’s midfield dynamo , Darren
Fletcher, was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis,

385.text:
a debilatating bowel disease. Terrified and
embarrassed, he confided in Sir Alex Ferguson.

391.text:
“Obviously, I’ve experienced a different
side of Sir Alex Ferguson during my illness

396.text:
and I’ve got the utmost respect for him
because he took football out of the equation

400.text:
and looked after me and made sure 
I looked after my family.”

404.text:
United dominated the 90s, winning 13 major
titles, with Ferguson building two trophy-winning

409.text:
teams. His process of regeneration wasn’t
just limited to the players. He had the foresight

415.text:
to introduce forward-thinking coaches
to help execute his vision.

420.text:
“When I call from Alex, as he was then,
I was at Derby County. We went into his wonderful

427.text:
office, we sat down and directly he asked
me the one question of the interview:

432.text:
‘How do I keep my team No.1?’ And I answered:
Think, behave and train like you’re No.2.

443.text:
And that hit the spot. His next question was:
‘When can you start?’”

448.text:
“Sir Alex made a decision. He decided to
double-up pre-season training and rather than

454.text:
just leaving the players to lay around on
the sofas between morning and afternoon sessions,

459.text:
we cleaned out one of the rooms at Carrington,
I put in some products which were effectively

464.text:
loungers, so at least up to 12 or 15 of the
players could go in there. That was principally

471.text:
the first ever time that a conversation had
been had with a club like that or anybody

477.text:
where we were actually encouraging athletes
to nap. That wonderful word. To actually take

483.text:
a controlled recovery period and go to sleep
in between sessions and to see the levels

489.text:
of if they went a little bit quicker in the
afternoon. It was so early days, people started

495.text:
to knock on the door: Sam Allardyce at Bolton,
Arsene Wenger and Gary Lewin at Arsenal,

501.text:
“He was open to all the methodologies that
he thought might help his players to be the

506.text:
best they can be. I had an open book to be
able to work with the players all the time.

511.text:
So, I went into the club to do some rehab
training with Roy Keane and we ended up producing

516.text:
boxing training which was really important.
It was a step different. You've got your weights,

521.text:
you've got your various abdominal core stuff
or whatever, but then you've got boxing training."

526.text:
"Something new was happening all the time,
I think. It's specific gym stuff, it's not

532.text:
just necessarily banging out weights, it's
all types of stuff – certain leg movements,

539.text:
mobility and we did bring that in early doors
and a lot of it was for preventing injury."

546.text:
By the time Sir Alex Ferguson called time
on his glittering career at Manchester United

551.text:
he had won 49 trophies in the most successful
managerial career that Britain has ever known.

557.text: His unrivalled achievements owe much to his insatiable desire for success and unique fashion sense.

563.text: "You see some of these managers and their preening themselves and they're very aware

568.text:
of their image. They're a bit vain or they're
very image conscious, whereas he's very just

574.text:
values conscious and people conscoius. I remember
when they won the European Cup in Moscow and

580.text:
it's chucked it down. John Terry slipped because
it was wet and they had these Paul Smith suits

589.text:
and shoes especially for the event and the
grass was soaking. These were pointy shoes

596.text:
that probably didn't suit him at all and by 
the time they got wet, they curled up... they were

601.text:
like Ali Baba shoes. It came to the banquet
at the end and he's doing a speech next to

607.text:
David Gill. He's standing there with a pair
of white trainers on and this flash suit.

612.text:
He doesn't give a damn about it, the people
here are is family and by that stage he's

618.text: the big granddad in front of his whole family. What does that matter? I could do this in my slippers this!"

624.text:
"He was a master of coming in at half-time
when you were drawing or losing and when you

630.text:
didn't expect him to go mental, he did. 
When you expected him to go mental, he was calm

634.text:
and he'd got to his tactic board and pinpoint
one or two little things that were usually

639.text:
the difference to go and win the game. It's
hard to explain because a lot of what he did

644.text:
was very simplistic but other times the true
genius came out. He mixed and matched really.

648.text:
Some of his team talks before big games were
hair-standing-up-on-the-back-of-you-neck stuff

653.text:
and you went out there with so much pride
and passion and desire to do well for him

658.text:
and to do well for yourself and to do well
as part of the club. That brought out the

663.text: best of us on big nights."

665.text:
"Driving from the Cliff to Old Trafford the
day after they won the league, he was on the

669.text:
phone talking about a transfer. You're thinking,
'He's not stopping... this guy's not stopping

676.text:
for a minute here. He's moving on to
the next thing. Once the final whistle blows

681.text:
on that league, you celebrate for a night
but there's almost like an anti climax. You've

686.text:
done all the work and then into an anti-climax,
but he was straight into the next thing.

693.text: He was incessant, he just wouldn't stop."

697.text:
"You've just won the treble, you keep the
same players again the motivation might not

701.text:
be there as much. If you start signing a few
players who are looking to get in the team

707.text: it all just kicks on again."

715.text:
Ferguson's win-at-all-costs mentality was
critical in helping restore United to their

720.text:
former greatness. But it was his ability to
observe and understand the human pscyhe that

727.text:
"He used to get there at 7 o'clock in the morning
and he would be overlooking the car park where

733.text:
everybody came into. But also he would overlook
the training pitches. He would see every player

739.text: get out of their car and see what mood they were in.

744.text: He's watching all his players, all the time."

749.text:
"Ronaldo had a really tough time for 
the first 18 months to two years

753.text: where the manager tried to toughen him up.

755.text:
When he kept hanging onto the ball too long 
and he wasn't delivering it into the box

760.text: and he was beating men two

761.text:
or three times, his end product wasn't quite
there, he learned the hard way – there's

765.text:
no doubt about that. He got kicked but that
was a way of telling him, 'If you do this,

771.text:
you're not helping the team and you're going
to get kicked in games'. I think he'll be

775.text:
the first to tell you that it was a tough
school at Manchester United at the time. We

778.text:
all experienced it, I experienced it and I
think that's part of what made him the best

783.text:
player in the world. And he also had a desire
to achieve things for Alex Ferguson who he

788.text:
respected greatly, and his teammates. I tell
you right how: Ronaldo loved every moment

791.text: of his time at Manchester United."

793.text:
"He was like a personal coach for everybody
in the club. Whether it be the gate man, the

799.text:
tea lady, the secretary, each player... he
had a personal impact on them – he touched

806.text:
them personally. Just small things. He'd put
a hot spoon on the back of the groundsman's

811.text:
neck at lunchtime but that groundsman then
goes away and tells all the lads in the groundsman's

818.text:
hut and tells his wife at home, 'That Fergie,
you know what he did today?!' It's a personal

825.text:
touch and he had the personal touch with everybody
which made it feel like a family."

831.text:
"He definitely mellowed a little bit, but
not completely. You still got a rollicking."

837.text:
"It was actually after he retired and I was
at his golf day. He came over and I said,

844.text:
'How you doing, gaffer?' And he said, 'No,
no, no... it's not gaffer anymore, it's Alex'.

847.text:
I said, 'Gaffer, I can't call you Alex, it's
not in my nature'. He still gets called the

855.text:
gaffer now because all the players have so
much respect for him and rightly so."
